thread.title: Megaupload: Dotcom Extradition Hearing Begins

author: news.sky
title: Megaupload: Dotcom Extradition Hearing Begins
text:
Kim Dotcom, the man behind file-sharing site Megaupload, has appeared in court to decide whether he can be extradited to the US. He is accused of facilitating piracy of film and music to the tune of more than $500m (£322m) and also faces racketeering and money laundering charges.
The entrepreneur has been locked in a three-year legal battle since armed police and helicopters raided his New Zealand mansion in 2012. 
Dotcom has used actors to make fun of the 2012 police raid on his house
Dotcom argues he is not responsible for the files that users shared on the site – which has since been shut down - and that may people used it for legitimate purposes.
The German-born entrepreneur claims he has back problems and was allowed to bring his own leather chair to the court hearing in Auckland.
1 / 11 Gallery: Tycoon Kim Dotcom's Turbulent Past
Born Kim Schmitz in Kiel, Germany, to a Finnish mother on January 21, 1974
He arrived in sunglasses and a cap, and pulled up in his Mercedes with the number plate KIM.COM.
It is claimed Megaupload and Dotcom raked in $175m (£112m) from the site’s users.
"This case is not just about me. This case is about how much control we allow US corporations and the US government to have over the internet," Dotcom said on Twitter.
After the hearing, he posted a cartoon of himself sitting in his chair in court and added: "It's totally uplifting to get so many good luck wishes from all over the Internet. One for all and all for one. #InternetFreedom."
Play video "Mar 2014: Dotcom Political Party" Video: Mar 2014: Dotcom Political Party The fate of three other Megaupload bosses - Mathias Ortmann, Bram van der Kolk and Finn Batato - will also be decided at the hearing.
Lawyers do not need to prove they are guilty, only that they have a case to answer in the US.
The hearing is expected to last up to a month.
